title: Women in their 40s earning more than those in their 30s for the first time, government data reveals
text:
Women in their 40s are earning more than those in their 30s for the first time, government data reveals, after companies were forced to publish gender pay gap figures.

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) today published a report on the gender pay gap in 2019.

It found that the gender pay gap has fallen to almost zero among full-time employees aged 40 and under. However overall, the gap for full-time workers in the UK has risen slightly to 8.9%.

This is in comparison to the previous year when it was 8.6% - which was also the lowest since records began in 1997, when it stood at 17.4%.

Sam Smethers, chief executive of the Fawcett Society, said: "Progress to close the gender pay gap is dismally slow and at this rate it will take 60 years to eradicate it.
